user_request: A Father's Day poem about a dad being a hero and role model.
final_poem:
# My Dad, the Quiet Hero

On weekdays he'd drive me to school
in that familiar hummer of his,
then wave from the curb like it meant
everything—or nothing at all.

But something it did. I watched him lock the car,
cross the parking lot with his hands full,
open every door for no one,
the small courtesies he practiced blind.

Weekends he was under the truck
changing filters, grease on his knuckles,
fixing whatever a house asks of you:
a wobbly table, a faucet that bled.

I never heard him name it. A hero
doesn't have to. He just does the thing
that keeps the kitchen lit, that fixes
the gate so the bike can find its circle again.

He didn't save a child in flood or fire.
No epic rescue worth retelling.

What he did: every Monday morning,
he met my mother's eyes across the table
and held still for what must have been
a small, fierce, beautiful negotiation—proof
that even grown men practice peace
in rooms where they're allowed to sit.

I'm learning. And I'm learning from him
the way a dog learns: by watching,
by trying the thing that brought a reward.

On this day, Father's Day, which feels
like a made-up holiday except for the truth it carries—
I want you to know: I see you.
I carry your quiet courage in my hands
when I change a lightbulb, when I stay
calm at the register with the woman who wronged me.

You didn't teach me that. No one does.
But I watched you for eighteen years,
and now I'm doing what you did
without being asked—sliding under things,
fixing them, holding still in the kitchen
when the argument comes to dinner.

Thank you. The quiet kind.
The kind that means everything.
